elements.content: A systematic investigation on solvent-dependent assembly of trinuclear copper cluhster has resulted in eight related coordination polymers: Cu3(teaH2)2(oba)2(MeOH)2 (1), Cu3(teaH2)2(oba)2(EtOH)2 (2), Cu3(teaH2)2(oba)2·(n-PrOH) (3), Cu3(teaH2)2(oba)2 (4), Cu3(teaH2)2(oba)2(H2O)2 (5), Cu3(MedeaH)2(oba)2(MeOH)2 (6), Cu­[Cu3(Medea)2(oba)2]·(solvent) x (7), and [Cu3(MedeaH)2(oba)2(H2O)]·(n-PrOH)2 (8) where oba = 4,4′-oxy-bis­(benzoate), teaH3 = triethanolamine, and MedeaH2 = N-methyldiethanolamine. In 1–8, the trinuclear copper secondary building units (SBUs) (Cu3) are furnished via the synergistic coordination of two organic ligands with metal centers. The structures of 1–8 exhibit two types of extensible modes (mode I for 1, 2, 3, 7, 8 and mode II for 4, 5, 6) to Cu3 SBUs. Mode I assembles Cu3 SBUs into the one-dimensional (1D) iron-chain-like structure while mode II facilitates the two-dimensional (2D) undulate rectangular (4, 4) connection. Compounds 1 and 2 feature zero-dimensional (0D) molecular structures in which two strong hydrogen-bonding interactions extend its molecular components into 1D chains. Compound 3 comprises 1D chains interspersed by free solvent molecules, whereas compound 4 consists of 2D sheets excluding any solvent molecules. Compound 5 is also made up of 0D molecular structures but uses two classic hydrogen-bonding interactions to form its 2D supramolecular connection. Compound 6 has a 2D network similar to 4. Compound 7 shows an unusual three-dimensional (3D) microporous framework in which a 1D chain is further assembled by extra CuII ions. Compound 8 provides 1D solvated structures with the voids occupied by lattice solvent molecules. The coordination ability of solvent molecules has been established for the underlying factor behind the different assemblies of compounds 1–8. Compounds 5 and 8 from an alcohol/H2O mixture indicate a behavior of selective coordination to the available coordination points of metal centers. The gas sorption property of compound 7 has also been investigated.

elements.content: The synergistic use of two chelating and bridging organic carboxylate and polyalcohol amines realized a rational route to construct definitive trinuclear copper secondary building units (SBUs). The solvent-dependent assemblies of the definitive SBUs have systematically illustrated the ability of solvent molecules as coordination/uncoordination ligands in tuning their crystal structures.
elements.clean_text: The synergistic use of two chelating and bridging organic carboxylate and polyalcohol amines realized a rational route to construct definitive trinuclear copper secondary building units (SBUs). The solvent-dependent assemblies of the definitive SBUs have systematically illustrated the ability of solvent molecules as coordination/uncoordination ligands in tuning their crystal structures.

elements.content: The increasing demands for multifunctional coordination polymers have stimulated extensive research in the area of crystal engineering. One issue of coordination polymers is to use definitive metal clusters to pursue their structural beauty. This synthetic strategy would endow the resultant complexes with important properties which may exert their potential in applications such as optical, magnetic, and porous materials. Now, the rapid development of metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) represents indeed a very successful example that employs secondary building units (SBUs). The rigid behavior of SBUs in MOFs families plays a key role in yielding robust frameworks. Moreover, this building-block strategy should help to improve our understanding of MOFs nets. However, for most coordination polymers, the realization of definitive metal clusters in a rational way remains a challenging issue in coordination chemistry.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The increasing demands for multifunctional coordination polymers have stimulated extensive research in the area of crystal engineering. One issue of coordination polymers is to use definitive metal clusters to pursue their structural beauty. This synthetic strategy would endow the resultant complexes with important properties which may exert their potential in applications such as optical, magnetic, and porous materials. Now, the rapid development of metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) represents indeed a very successful example that employs secondary building units (SBUs). The rigid behavior of SBUs in MOFs families plays a key role in yielding robust frameworks. Moreover, this building-block strategy should help to improve our understanding of MOFs nets. However, for most coordination polymers, the realization of definitive metal clusters in a rational way remains a challenging issue in coordination chemistry.

elements.content: As popular polytopic linkers, the organic carboxylate ligands are widely employed in providing SBUs of the MOFs family because they possess chelating and bridging capabilities from COO groups. It is obvious that carboxylate linkers have been one main target for modifications in order to impart desired properties. Similar to carboxylate linkers, polyalcohol amines can be partly deprotonated to give multipodal anions acting as bridging and chelating ligands for synthesizing polynuclear species. To satisfy charge balance, another coligand is generally indispensable for their resultant metal clusters. Up to now, much attention has been paid to synthesize homo-/heteronuclear single-molecule magnets (SMMs). The particular behavior allows them to be promising candidates for designing beautiful metal building blocks. However, the introduction of polyalcohol amines into SBUs of the MOFs family has hitherto received little attention. With these serendipities in mind, we are currently exploring valuable insights into the synergistic coordination of polyalcohol amines and organic carboxylates with metal centers.

elements.content: Apart from the important factor of ligand selection, the self-assembly progress of the definitive metal clusters is highly affected by several factors such as solvents, templates (or guests), temperature counterions, and so on. Among these factors, the solvent influence is less well understood and systematic study is rare. The solvent effects can be generally explained in terms of their difference in size, shape, and coordination ability. It should be noteworthy that many metal clusters involved in polyalcohol amines can provide themselves with available coordination points of metal centers. These surplus coordination points might make solvent molecules accessible. It is very conceivable that the coordination ability of solvent molecules can dramatically affect their structural assemblies. Therefore, taking the aforementioned topic into account, we are also interested in our focus on the solvent-dependent assemblies of SBUs containing polyalcohol amines. In this work, varying the solvothermal reactions from MeOH to PrOH and then to the alcohol/H2O mixture results in eight related coordination polymers, namely, zero-dimensional (0D) Cu3(teaH2)2(oba)2(MeOH)2 (1), Cu3(teaH2)2(oba)2(EtOH)2 (2), and Cu3(teaH2)2(oba)2(H2O)2 (5), one-dimensional (1D) Cu3(teaH2)2(oba)2·(PrOH) (3), and [Cu3(MedeaH)2(oba)2(H2O)]·(PrOH)2 (8), two-dimensional (2D) Cu3(teaH2)2(oba)2 (4), and Cu3(MedeaH)2(oba)2(MeOH)2 (6), and three-dimensional (3D) Cu­[Cu3(Medea)2(oba)2]·(solvent) x (7). Their structural evolutions are involved in the remarkably solvent-dependent assembly of Cu3 SBUs. This contribution deals with two important aspects: (1) the cooperation of polyalcohol amines (teaH3: triethanolamine and MedeaH2: N-methyldiethanolamine) and 4,4′-oxy-bis­(benzoate) (oba) ensures the repetition for consistent Cu3 SBUs; (2) the solvent coordination ability determines the resultant frameworks. We report herein their syntheses and crystal structures. In addition, the detailed characterizations of TG investigations and powder X-ray diffractions for 1–8 are presented. A gas sorption experiment of 7 has also been investigated, and variable-temperature magnetic susceptibility measurements were taken for samples 6–8.

elements.content: All reagents were purchased from commercial sources and used without further purification. CHN elemental analysis was conducted on a Perkin-Elmer 240C element analyzer. Thermogravimetric analysis was performed using a Pyris Diamond thermal analyzer. Powder X-ray diffraction data were collected using a Bruker D8 Advance (Cu Kα1 radiation, λ = 1.5406 Å). The nitrogen adsorption–desorption isotherm was obtained on a BET surface area analyzer (ASAP-2020). Variable-temperature magnetic susceptibility measurements were carried out using SQUID magnetometer MPMS XL-7 (Quantum Design) at 1.0 kOe in the temperature range of 2–300 K.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Physical Measurements

All reagents were purchased from commercial sources and used without further purification. CHN elemental analysis was conducted on a Perkin-Elmer 240C element analyzer. Thermogravimetric analysis was performed using a Pyris Diamond thermal analyzer. Powder X-ray diffraction data were collected using a Bruker D8 Advance (Cu Kα1 radiation, λ = 1.5406 Å). The nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherm was obtained on a BET surface area analyzer (ASAP-2020). Variable-temperature magnetic susceptibility measurements were carried out using SQUID magnetometer MPMS XL-7 (Quantum Design) at 1.0 kOe in the temperature range of 2-300 K.

elements.content: A mixture of Cu­(NO3)2·3H2O (0.0314 g, 0.13 mmol) and obaH2 (0.0336 g, 0.13 mmol) in methanol (10 mL) was stirred for 10 min, and then 4 drops of teaH3 was added to the mixture with further stirring for 20 min. The resultant solution was transferred into a 17 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel container and heated at 120 °C for 24 h. After being cooled to room temperature, blue block crystals of 1 were collected in 86.5% yield based on the added amounts of Cu­(NO3)2·3H2O. Elemental analysis: Calcd: C, 47.43; H, 4.93; N, 2.63, Found: C, 47.31; H, 4.82; N, 2.74.

elements.content: A Bruker Appex II CCD diffractometer equipped with graphite monochromatized Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71069 Å) was used to collect X-ray intensity data. Diffraction intensities for compounds 1–4 were collected on 173 K and the other four compounds on 298 K. Absorption corrections were applied using the multiscan technique. The structures were solved by direct methods using SHELXS-97 and refined with full-matrix least-squares techniques using the SHELXL-97 program within WINGX. All C-bound H atoms were refined using a riding model. The hydroxy H atoms were located in a difference Fourier map and their positions were refined under the application of an O–H bond-length restraint of 0.90(1), with U iso(H) values set at 1.5U eq(O). Experimental details of the X-ray analyses are provided in Table .
elements.clean_text:
Single Crystal Structure Determination

A Bruker Appex II CCD diffractometer equipped with graphite monochromatized Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71069 Å) was used to collect X-ray intensity data. Diffraction intensities for compounds 1-4 were collected on 173 K and the other four compounds on 298 K. Absorption corrections were applied using the multiscan technique. The structures were solved by direct methods using SHELXS-97 and refined with full-matrix least-squares techniques using the SHELXL-97 program within WINGX. All C-bound H atoms were refined using a riding model. The hydroxy H atoms were located in a difference Fourier map and their positions were refined under the application of an O-H bond-length restraint of 0.90(1), with U iso(H) values set at 1.5U eq(O). Experimental details of the X-ray analyses are provided in Table .

Compounds 1–7 have a CuII/polyalcohol amines/oba ratio of 3:2:2. Although we varied their added ratio in the reaction mixtures, consistent Cu3 SBUs in compounds 1–8 were obtained. Crystallographical analyses of compounds 1–8 reveal two types of extensible modes (modes I and II in Scheme ) which extend the Cu3 components to their final structures. Selected bond lengths and angles for compounds 1–8 are listed in Table .

Compound 1 is isostructural to 2 and crystallizes in the centrosymmetric space group P1̅. As shown in Figure a, X-ray single-crystal analysis reveals that 1 feature a 0D molecule with its Cu3 SBUs terminally appended by two oba ligands. In compound 1, there are one mono-deprotonated teaH2 ligand, one oba ligand, and one methanol molecule as well as two crystallographically independent CuII centers per asymmetric unit. The Cu1 atom resides on the center of inversion with half a population so that a linear trinuclear copper entity is equivalently furnished. The Cu1 center completes its six-coordination octahedral environment by three oxygen atoms and their symmetry-related equivalents from teaH2, oba, and methanol, respectively. Another Cu2 center shows trigonal bipyramidal coordination geometry with three O atoms of teaH2 ligand in equatorial positions and the teaH2 N atom and one carboxylate O atom in axial positions. Although only one carboxylate moiety of oba ligand bridges two CuII ions in η2-O1, O2 manner, one N atom and three alkoxide arm O atoms of teaH2 chelate the Cu2 atom, whereas the deprotonated alkoxo group O atom serves as a μ2-O bridging species. The Cu–O bond distances (1.9661(14) and 2.2872(16) Å) involved in hydroxyl O atoms of teaH2 is somewhat longer than that (1.8920(14) Å) including deprotonated one but significantly shorter than the value (2.490 Å) found in methanol coordination interactions. The shortest length of Cu–O bond is assigned to deprotonated μ2-alkoxo bridging intersections, which is in agreement with those values in other related literature reports and the following crystallographical observations. The bond angle values of O–Cu–O around Cu1 center range from 88.58(6) to 91.42(6)° , indicating a slightly distorted octahedral environment. The significant distortion of the trigonal bipyramidal coordination geometry around the Cu2 center is manifested by the cis O–Cu–O angles, which lie in the range 104.40(6)–148.64(7)°.

elements.content: Crystal structure of 1: (a) ORTEP view of coordination environments around Cu3 SBUs (thermal ellipsoid probability: 30%. All hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity); (b) the detailed hydrogen bonding interactions among neighboring molecules (dashed green lines); and (c) packing diagrams of the 1D iron-chain-like structure of 1 formed by the two classic hydrogen bonds (green) (H atoms not involved in hydrogen bonding have been omitted for clarity).
elements.clean_text: 1  Crystal structure of 1: (a) ORTEP view of coordination environments around Cu3 SBUs (thermal ellipsoid probability: 30%. All hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity); (b) the detailed hydrogen bonding interactions among neighboring molecules (dashed green lines); and (c) packing diagrams of the 1D iron-chain-like structure of 1 formed by the two classic hydrogen bonds (green) (H atoms not involved in hydrogen bonding have been omitted for clarity).

elements.content: It should be noticeable that each molecule in compounds 1 and 2 strongly interacts with two neighboring molecules via two classic hydrogen bonds (Figure b and Table ) by means of mode I, resulting in a 1D iron-chain-like arrangement with end-to-end closed circles. The catenulate structure is parallelly packed through van der Waals forces instead of hydrogen bonds (Figure c). Although the CuII ion can extend its coordination number from 5 to 6, the remaining carboxylate moiety of oba ligand allows the formation of classic hydrogen bonds rather than the sixth coordination interaction.

It is only the subtle differences in unit cells that are raised by changing methanol thermal to ethanol thermal protocol. Studies on the MeOH/EtOH mixture recipes have shown that the resultant frameworks prefer methanol to coordinate to the Cu1 center rather than ethanol even though at the volume ratio of 10:1. The special behavior should be attributed to their differences in coordination ability. Encouraged by this interesting result, we aim at investigating the effect from n-PrOH and n-BuOH with lower coordination ability. Compound 3 is propanol thermally prepared and crystallizes in the centrosymmetric space group C2/c. Compared with compounds 1 and 2, 3 consists of 1D chains interspersed by free propanol molecules. In compound 3, each Cu atom in Cu3 SBUs is octahedrally coordinated and held together through four μ2-O atoms from two teaH2 ligands, and each oba ligand has a μ3-η2η1 connection mode toward three CuII ions (Figure ). Still, the Cu3 SBUs have an end-to-end arrangement by means of mode I. A noteworthy feature of 3 is the occurrence of an intercrossed angle (approximate 35.78°) among adjacent iron-chain-like structures (Figure b), which results in a roomed packing. The total solvent-accessible volume in the unit cell is 1426.3 Ǻ3 for 3, accounting for approximately 28.3% of the total cell volume as calculated by PLATON. The n-PrOH molecules occupy the available voids in 3.

elements.content: Since the n-PrOH solvent molecules are unable to coordinate to Cu ions and play the only role as lattice guest molecules, the replacement of n-PrOH by n-BuOH must present a structure without covalent butanol. However, the butanol thermal reaction results in structural variant and a new compound 4 is isolated. Its framework is made up of 2D undulate rectangular (4, 4) sheets excluding any solvent molecules. In the Cu3 SBUs of 4 (Figure a), the Cu2 centers located laterally adopt an octahedral coordination environment. The Cu1 center on the inversion, unlike that in 3, is preferably described as square coordination geometry or pseudo-octahedral one because of the further axial Cu–O interactions at a longer distance of 3.104 Å for Cu1–O6 which are significantly larger than the sum of the van der Waals radii of Cu and O. The oba ligand has the same μ3-η2η1 connection mode to 3, and yet it links each Cu3 SBUs with four neighboring ones by means of mode II. Thus a 2D polymeric structure of 4 is formed with the Cu3 SBUs acting as a planar four-connected node and the oba ligand as a μ2-tether. On the basis of the Cu1–Cu1 distances, the approximate dimensions of the (4, 4) grids are 15.906 Å × 15.906 Å, allowing the offset embedment of Cu3 SBUs into such voids. Therefore, neither free solvent molecules nor interpenetrating incident appears in the so dense structure (Figure b). From the structural assemblies of 3 and 4, it can be seen that the replacement of n-PrOH by n-BuOH has also large effects on the overall structures. This difference is possibly generated from the different templated effect of solvent molecules and the flexibility of the oba ligand at ether bonding.

elements.content: A prominent feature for solvent control in our studies is attributed to their differences in coordination ability. The Cu3 SBUs in 1–4 are very stable and can afford available coordination points for solvent molecules on the inversion center Cu1 atoms. In other words, once guest molecules can bond covalently to host frameworks, the recognition behavior could be achieved in selective coordination fashion among mixed solvent systems. This hypothesis is further illustrated by the fact that compound 5 is isolated from an alcohol/H2O mixture regardless of alcohol solvent varieties. To obtain suitable crystals for single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis, a large number of attempts are raised and the optional recipe succeeds in a propanol/H2O mixture at a volume ratio of 17:1. It is quite reasonable that the powerful coordination ability of the water molecule makes its intrusion feasible. Studies have shown that trace amounts of water (∼5%) can beat the alcohol solvents to coordinate to the inversion center Cu1 atoms. Although compound 5 possesses the same asymmetric unit to 1–2 except for coordination water molecules (Figure a), its crystalline system is transformed into the centrosymmetric monoclinic space group P21/c. This might be an indication of different packing behavior. In contrast to 1–2, 5 is also made up of a 0D molecular structure but facilitates its 2D undulate rectangular (4, 4) connections by virtue of two hydrogen bonds (Table and Figure b,c) according to mode II. Taking hydrogen bonds into account and consulting topologic analysis, we find that compound 5 shows the same topological structure to that of 4. Their structures are different in the interpenetrating degree in order to avoid empty voids. The dimensions of the (4, 4) grids are 16.383 Å × 16.383 Å as measured between Cu1–Cu1 sites of 5. In Champness’ opinion, longer ligands might lead to a greater degree of interpenetration. It should be rationalized for 5 (Figure d) that a 3-fold interpenetrating net is indispensable to satisfy its close packing because of the longer hydrogen bonding interactions.

elements.content: From the structures of 1–5, it can be obviously seen that the solvent molecules have exerted remarkable controllability over their overall structural extensions in terms of the coordination order of H2O > MeOH > EtOH > PrOH. Compounds 1–5 exhibit variable frameworks though the special Cu3 SBUs is precisely defined. After careful analysis for inherent structural evolutions, this uncertain assembly arises from three important factors: (1) the existence of various coordination environments for a given Cu metal (for example, Cu2 center has a coordination numbers from 5 to 6 in our observations); (2) the dual hydrogen bonding donations from two hydroxyl arms of teaH2 molecules; (3) the extraordinary flexibility of oba ligand at ether bonding. The two classic hydrogen bonds in 1, 2, and 5 are superior to the sixth coordination interaction, while the rivalship gives a way to the coordination number enhancement in 3 and 4. The lower the coordination ability of solvent molecules is, the more evident the tendency to six-coordination is. In the case of this competition, the extraordinary flexibility of the oba ligand seems to affect the extensible mode corresponding to the solvent controllability. Specifically speaking, the dihedral angle between two phenyl rings of oba molecule is significantly different for 1–5 (71.12, 71.88, 87.87, 65.66, and 66.75°, respectively). It is quite obvious that the dihedral angle values in 1D mode I assembly are significantly greater than those of 2D mode II structures. This incident will reappear in crystallographical observations of compounds 6–8.

elements.content: On the contrary, unlike the variable assembly, the particular fixation of Cu3 SBUs is unprecedented and derives from the synergistic coodination of two organic ligands as typical bridging and chelating reagents. Polyalcohol amines can behave as base medium from the amine fragment and favor the deprotonation of carboxylate ligand. On the other hand, Polyalcohol amines can be partly deprotonated themselves and then integrate the μ-bridging O atoms from two ligands into particularly stable entities. To provide a further understanding of this synergistic effect, we select N-methyldiethanolamine (MedeaH2), a similar candidate with only two alcohol arms, as the synergistic reagent to construct SBUs. Our aim is to both ensure the reappearance of Cu3 SBUs under the solvent-dependent recipes and create extensible opportunities on the outside Cu2 sites. Meanwhile, the replacement of one alcohol arm by a methyl group might rule out the dual hydroxyl hydrogen bonds. This strategy does open a new avenue for diversiform assembly.

elements.content: Changing teaH3 to MedeaH2 under methanol thermal conditions produced 6, a 2D network with undulate (4, 4) grids. X-ray single-crystal analysis reveals that, as expected, the Cu3 SBUs remain intact and become coordination unsaturated on the outside metal sites. Similar to TeaH3, the MedeaH2 molecule in 6 is mono-deprotonated to give rise to MedeaH anion. Each such anion combines its chelating and bridging capabilities with bis­(monodentate) bridging behavior of one carboxylate moiety of oba ligand to furnish three copper centers together. Compound 6 has the unit cell similar to 4 rather than to 1, which is a hint of mode II assembly. Indeed, each Cu3 SBUs is linked to four neighboring ones through the biphenyl fragment of the oba molecule and each oba ligand connects with two Cu3 SBUs using μ3-η2η1 coordination manner. In the Cu3 SBUs of 6 (Figure ), the inversion center Cu1 atom shows the accordant coordination environment with 1. Three coordinated atoms from MedeaH molecule and one O atom of oba occupy four coordination points on each outside Cu2 center. The remaining position is set aside for the O atom from another oba ligand. The absence of one alcohol arm in the MedeaH molecule destroys the foundation of dual hydroxyl hydrogen bonds between MedeaH and oba ligands. Finally, these differences from that observed in 1 result in the mode II arrangement instead of that of 1. It is obvious that the removing of one available chelating-arm in MedeaH2 is very sensible for providing extensible opportunities. The Cu1–Cu1 distances of the (4, 4) grids (15.337 Å × 15.337 Å) in 6 are comparable to those found in 4, which suggests a similar offset packing of 2D layers to 4.

elements.content: In subsequent reactions about solvent-dependent protocols, we established that compound 7 can be formed under any solvothermal conditions including EtOH, n-PrOH, or n-BuOH. The propanol thermal procedure can markedly increase the quality and quantity of crystals suitable for single-crystal X-ray diffraction studies. This observation demonstrates that 7 is independent of the coordination order among three given solvents and no solvent molecules can directly coordinate to host frameworks of 7. The obtained diffraction data can be well refined for the guest-free structures even though the occluded solvent molecules cannot be crystallographically defined. The presence of solvent molecules is confirmed by TG curves. Compound 7 crystallizes in the centrosymmetric space group C2/c and exhibits an unusual microporous 3D framework with different open channels along all three crystallographical axes. Part of the structure of compound 7 is shown in Figure a. The asymmetric unit of the host framework contains three Cu centers (Cu1 and Cu3 at special positions with half an occupation, and one crystallographically independent Cu2), one bi-deprotonated Medea and one oba molecules. Each Cu atom at a special position is octahedrally coordinated by three O atoms and their symmetry-related equivalents from four oba and two Medea molecules. The Cu1 atom is located on the inversion center of the total framework while another Cu3 atom rests on the center of a 2-fold rotation axis. The Cu2 atom adopts a square-pyramidal geometry with the O4 atom of one oba molecule in the axial position as well as the O1 atom of another oba ligand and three coordinated atoms of one Medea molecule on equatorial positions. It is worth noting that oba ligand has a symmetric μ6-η1(η1-μ2)­η1(η1-μ2) connective fashion toward six CuII ions in 7. On the basis of the Cambridge Crystallographic Database, such an unusual fashion is observed for the first time in complexes containing oba ligand. The two alcohol arms of Medea are deprotonated so that Medea serves as a double μ2-alkoxo bridging species. The unique manner is manifested by the fact that its two Cu–O distances (1.911(5)–1.950(5) Å) are comparable to those involved in monodeprotonated ones.

elements.content: Crystal structure of 7: (a) ORTEP view of coordination environments around polynuclear copper centers (thermal ellipsoid probability: 30%); (b) SBUs with inorganic polynuclear chain comprised of side-shared CuO4N square-pyramids (blue) and CuO6 octahedra (pink); (c) view of microporous 3D framework with inorganic SBUs linked alternately via biphenyl rings of oba; (d) packing diagrams of microporous 3D framework along the c axis, exhibiting a wheel-shaped profile. Three colors are used to evidence the different positions of Cu centers generated; and (e) a better insight into the draw-out wheel, representing the further assembly of the 1D iron-chain-like structure into a 3D microporous framework by extra CuII ions (black) (all hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity).
elements.clean_text: 6  Crystal structure of 7: (a) ORTEP view of coordination environments around polynuclear copper centers (thermal ellipsoid probability: 30%); (b) SBUs with inorganic polynuclear chain comprised of side-shared CuO4N square-pyramids (blue) and CuO6 octahedra (pink); (c) view of microporous 3D framework with inorganic SBUs linked alternately via biphenyl rings of oba; (d) packing diagrams of microporous 3D framework along the c axis, exhibiting a wheel-shaped profile. Three colors are used to evidence the different positions of Cu centers generated; and (e) a better insight into the draw-out wheel, representing the further assembly of the 1D iron-chain-like structure into a 3D microporous framework by extra CuII ions (black) (all hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity).

elements.content: The chelating and bridging pattern from oba and Medea is repeated infinitely to form inorganic polynuclear chains. At first glance, the inorganic chain is regarded as a new SBU comprised of side-shared CuO4N square-pyramids and CuO6 octahedra (Figure b). Viewed down the crystallographic a or b axes, these chains are arrayed in a crossed manner so that each inorganic chain is linked to alternate ones through organic moieties of oba molecules, resulting in a microporous 3D framework (Figure c). However, a better insight into the nature of the involuted framework can be achieved by the application of a relevancy to the extensible mode I. It is obviously seen that, down the crystallographic c axes, a wheel-shaped profile is built from the circling of Cu2 atoms, Medea, and oba molecules around the Cu1 centers. Each such wheel is connected to four neighboring wheels through the peripheral Cu3 atoms in their four corners (Figure d). To our surprise, we find that the draw-out wheel is actually an iron-chain-like structure in which Cu3 SBUs are in accordant assembly of mode I with that of 1–3. Their Cu3 SBUs originate from the linear ligation of the inversion center Cu1 atom and two symmetry-related Cu2 atoms. The differences are that all chains in 7 parallelly interact with each other by the covalent connections at interval Cu3 atoms instead of the superlattice packing from van der Waals forces in 1–3.

elements.content: Despite the recurrence of Cu3 SBUs and mde I assembly in 7 from the above analysis, the unexpectable connection on the outside Cu2 sites is attributed to the uncoordination of three given solvents to the inversion center Cu1 atom. Although one carboxylate end of oba and one alkoxo arm of Medea are used to ligate Cu3 SBUs, the Cu1 and Cu2 centers remain with coordination points. The O4 atoms from another carboxylate end make use of the η1-μ2 bridging fashion to both complete the two axial positions of Cu1 centers and saturate the coordination number of Cu2 sites. This adjustment compels the transformation of Cu2 configuration from trigonal bipyramidal geometry in 6 to a square-pyramidal environment in 7 as well as the inclination of the carboxylate end toward Cu3 SBUs. The exceptional extension on the outside Cu2 sites may be the suitable conformation to satisfy the steric impulse from fixing the square-pyramidal environment and inclining carboxylate end. The second alcohol arm of Medea is also deprotonated in that it is requirable to introduce extra Cu3 atom. That is to say, those solvents with the poor coordination ability perform the most perfect control over the resultant 3D frameworks of 7.

elements.content: Again, the most striking structural feature of 7 is the further assembly of a 1D iron-chain-like structure into a 3D microporous framework by extra CuII ions (Figure e). This unique assembly adds a new variable to the toolbox of our present studies. Compound 7 forms three axial channels going through its void structure. The solvent molecules are trapped uncoordinatedly inside the framework. The total solvent-accessible volume in the unit cell is 1597.8 Ǻ3 for 7, accounting for approximately 29.5% of the total cell volume as calculated by PLATON. The disorder was limited to the solvents and may be due to the large amount of available space in the channels of the structure.

elements.content: The selective coordination of solvent molecule is generally related to the differences in coordination ability. Similar to the synthesis of 5, a trace amount of water is added into the solvothermal systems of 6–7 in order to once more recognize its desirable priority in coordination ability. Good-quality single crystals of 8 were carefully picked out when they were prepared through mixing various ratios and types of alcohol/H2O. The optimal data collection was detected in the case of n-PrOH/H2O at a 20:1 volume ratio. The distinctive unit cell implies a new structural variety for 8. Compound 8 has a 1D iron-chain-like structure and crystallizes in the centrosymmetric space group C2/c. In comparison with the structural varieties for 1–7, the especially different item is that 8 possesses nonlinear Cu3 SBUs rather than linear one (Figure a,b). A single-crystal X-ray diffraction study reveals that the Cu1 center in Cu3 SBUs shows a trigonal bipyramidal environment with only one water molecule occupying one equatorial position. Both the Cu1 atom and its attached water O atom are at special positions with half an occupation in the asymmetric unit. They rest on the 2-fold rotation axis so that the Cu1 atom and the two symmetry-related Cu2 atoms are in nonlinear array. It is obvious that the intrusions of water molecules induce the deformation of linear Cu3 SBUs. Compound 8 extends its Cu3 SBUs into a iron-chain-like structure by means of mode I instead of mode II in 6. In addition, 8 forms a solvated structure with the voids occupied by lattice n-PrOH molecules even though each chain is parallelly packed through van der Waals forces (Figure c). The coexistence of water and n-PrOH solvent molecules in the structure of 8 appears to confirm their coordination order from selective attachment.

They rest on the 2-fold rotation axis so that the Cu1 atom and the two symmetry-related Cu2 atoms are in nonlinear array. It is obvious that the intrusions of water molecules induce the deformation of linear Cu3 SBUs. Compound 8 extends its Cu3 SBUs into a iron-chain-like structure by means of mode I instead of mode II in 6. In addition, 8 forms a solvated structure with the voids occupied by lattice n-PrOH molecules even though each chain is parallelly packed through van der Waals forces (Figure c). The coexistence of water and n-PrOH solvent molecules in the structure of 8 appears to confirm their coordination order from selective attachment.

elements.content: For the diversiform assemblies of coordination polymers 1–8, the role of alcohol solvent in tuning structural assembly has been clearly demonstrated according to their coordination ability. The consistent Cu3 SBU has also been perfectly presented because of the synergistic coordination of two chelating and bridging ligands. The carboxylate moiety of the oba ligand can use different coordination modes to chelate and bridge polymetallic centers. Polyalcohol amines facilitate their chelating effect from alcohol arms and amine fragment but achieve the bridging ability via the deprotonated alkoxo arms. This integration between two ligands declares the foundation of one stable entity regardless of their structural assembly. By varying the solvent-dependent protocols, we obtained eight related compounds with two types of extensible modes. These representative compounds show great discrepancy in structural assemblies of Cu3 SBUs mainly corresponding to the presence or absence of the coordinated solvent. So, the coordination ability of the solvent molecules is the underlying factor behind the discrepancy.

elements.content: Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed using a Pyris Diamond thermal analyzer. Approximately 20 mg of products 1–8 were heated under a N2 atmosphere in the temperature range RT-800 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C min–1. As shown in Figure , TGA of samples 1–8 indicates that their host frameworks are stable up to 200 °C and are finally converted into the crystalline copper oxides in agreement with the overall mass loss (approximately 78 wt %). The TG curves of 1–2 show that the thermal decompositions take place in three stages: (1) First, removing coordinated alcohol molecules (weight loss: for 1, observed: 4.86 wt %, calc: 6.02 wt %; for 2, observed: 5.93 wt %, calc: 8.44 wt %); (2) The second stage is a process to eliminate the tea ligand within the range of 210–300 °C; (3) finally, decomposing organic oba linkers above 300 °C. The release of the tea ligand prior to the organic oba linker has been documented. In comparison with the TG behaviors of 1–2, thermal decomposition of 6 has no sudden desolvented stage which suggests the stronger coordination interactions between alcohol molecule and host framework. Compounds 3, 7, and 8 are characterized by a desolvented process corresponding to the removal of lattice alcohol molecules. The events agree well with single-crystal X-ray diffraction studies. The final weight loss of residue for 7 is lower (approximate 70 wt %) than those of any other compounds, which agrees well with its proposed structure with extra copper ion. No weight loss is observed for 4 until 200 °C and for 5 until 150 °C. The TGA analysis of 5 indicates that coordination H2O molecules and tea ligand are lost in continuous steps in the range of 150–300 °C, with weight loss of 30.20 wt % (calc: 32.09 wt %), and it is difficult to assign each weight loss separately.

The release of the tea ligand prior to the organic oba linker has been documented. In comparison with the TG behaviors of 1-2, thermal decomposition of 6 has no sudden desolvented stage which suggests the stronger coordination interactions between alcohol molecule and host framework. Compounds 3, 7, and 8 are characterized by a desolvented process corresponding to the removal of lattice alcohol molecules. The events agree well with single-crystal X-ray diffraction studies. elements.content: The framework stability of samples 7 provides an opportunity to probe gas adsorption properties. Compound 7 exhibits a porous framework from single-crystal X-ray diffraction study and can retain the host framework toward thermal treatment from a desolvented process. We examined the permanent porosity of 7 generated by activation under high vacuum at 180 °C for 24 h. Standard N2 sorption measurements revealed that, as expected from the structural analysis, the porosity could be detected corresponding to the appreciable adsorbed amount of 81.75 cm3g–1 at 0.98 P/P 0 and 196 K (Figure ). Moreover, the isotherm exhibited large hysteretic desorption behavior, suggesting the existence of molecular gates for its host framework. The isotherm gave an apparent Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) surface area of 159.4 m2 g–1 between relative pressures of 0.11 and 0.98, which is moderate.
elements.clean_text:
Gas Adsorption and Desorption Studies

The framework stability of samples 7 provides an opportunity to probe gas adsorption properties. Compound 7 exhibits a porous framework from single-crystal X-ray diffraction study and can retain the host framework toward thermal treatment from a desolvented process. We examined the permanent porosity of 7 generated by activation under high vacuum at 180 °C for 24 h. Standard N2 sorption measurements revealed that, as expected from the structural analysis, the porosity could be detected corresponding to the appreciable adsorbed amount of 81.75 cm3g-1 at 0.98 P/P 0 and 196 K (Figure ). Moreover, the isotherm exhibited large hysteretic desorption behavior, suggesting the existence of molecular gates for its host framework. The isotherm gave an apparent Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area of 159.4 m2 g-1 between relative pressures of 0.11 and 0.98, which is moderate.

elements.content: The temperature-dependent magnetic susceptibility of compounds 6–8 has been measured under a 1 kOe applied field in the temperature range of 2–300 K (Figure ). At room temperature (300 K) effective magnetic moments of 0.85 (6), 1.55 (7), and 1.13 cm3·K·mol–1 (8) were observed. With decreasing temperature the χM T values increase gradually and pass through maxima at 2.98 K, 2.05 cm3·K·mol–1 (6), 2.98 K, 2.82 cm3·K·mol–1 (7), and 9.5 K, 2.03 cm3·K·mol–1 (8). Such behavior is characteristic of predominant ferromagnetic exchange coupling in Cu3 SBUs. Moreover, ferromagnetic coupling in Cu3 SBUs is largely determined by the Cu3 conformation. For 7, the extra CuII ions interact with Cu3 SBUs to give an inorganic polynuclear chain with much more overlap between the magnetic orbitals of the copper centers, resulting in a higher χM T value. The exchange coupling among Cu3 centers is also influenced by whether the Cu3 SBUs is angled or linear. The corresponding χM T value of 6 is somewhat smaller than that of 8, confirming a slightly weak coupling among linear Cu3 SBUs.

Magnetic Properties

The temperature-dependent magnetic susceptibility of compounds 6-8 has been measured under a 1 kOe applied field in the temperature range of 2-300 K (Figure ). At room temperature (300 K) effective magnetic moments of 0.85 (6), 1.55 (7), and 1.13 cm3⋅K⋅mol-1 (8) were observed. With decreasing temperature the χM T values increase gradually and pass through maxima at 2.98 K, 2.05 cm3⋅K⋅mol-1 (6), 2.98 K, 2.82 cm3⋅K⋅mol-1 (7), and 9.5 K, 2.03 cm3⋅K⋅mol-1 (8). Such behavior is characteristic of predominant ferromagnetic exchange coupling in Cu3 SBUs. Moreover, ferromagnetic coupling in Cu3 SBUs is largely determined by the Cu3 conformation. For 7, the extra CuII ions interact with Cu3 SBUs to give an inorganic polynuclear chain with much more overlap between the magnetic orbitals of the copper centers, resulting in a higher χM T value. The exchange coupling among Cu3 centers is also influenced by whether the Cu3 SBUs is angled or linear. The corresponding χM T value of 6 is somewhat smaller than that of 8, confirming a slightly weak coupling among linear Cu3 SBUs.

elements.content: In summary, we succeeded in designing a rational route to construct stable Cu3 SBUs containing available coordination points and to assemble the specific components into variable frameworks under solvent control. Eight related coordination polymers with organic dicarboxylate (oba) and polyalcohol amines (TeaH3 and MedeaH2) as chelating and bridging ligands have been prepared under different solvothermal conditions. The structural evolutions from 0D to 3D have systematically illustrated the roles of solvent molecules as coordination/uncoordination molecules in tuning the assemblies of the definitive Cu3 SBUs. Given the large variety of the two used ligands, the scope of the further synthesis of other solvent-dependent compounds appears to be very inspiring. In addition, our findings might be a starting point to carry out further applications in the area of guest molecule recognitions.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In summary, we succeeded in designing a rational route to construct stable Cu3 SBUs containing available coordination points and to assemble the specific components into variable frameworks under solvent control. Eight related coordination polymers with organic dicarboxylate (oba) and polyalcohol amines (TeaH3 and MedeaH2) as chelating and bridging ligands have been prepared under different solvothermal conditions. The structural evolutions from 0D to 3D have systematically illustrated the roles of solvent molecules as coordination/uncoordination molecules in tuning the assemblies of the definitive Cu3 SBUs. Given the large variety of the two used ligands, the scope of the further synthesis of other solvent-dependent compounds appears to be very inspiring. In addition, our findings might be a starting point to carry out further applications in the area of guest molecule recognitions.

A mixture of Cu­(NO3)2·3H2O (0.0314 g, 0.13 mmol) and obaH2 (0.0336 g, 0.13 mmol) in methanol (10 mL) was stirred for 10 min, and then 4 drops of teaH3 was added to the mixture with further stirring for 20 min. The resultant solution was transferred into a 17 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel container and heated at 120 °C for 24 h. After being cooled to room temperature, blue block crystals of 1 were collected in 86.5% yield based on the added amounts of Cu­(NO3)2·3H2O. Elemental analysis: Calcd: C, 47.43; H, 4.93; N, 2.63, Found: C, 47.31; H, 4.82; N, 2.74.

2 was synthesized by a procedure similar to that used for 1 except that equal volumes of EtOH solvent were used in place of MeOH. Yield: 66.8% based on the added amounts of Cu­(NO3)2·3H2O. Elemental analysis: Calcd: C, 48.41; H, 5.17; N, 2.57, Found: C, 48.35; H, 5.09; N, 2.66.

cln_elements.content:
Again, the most striking structural feature of 7 is the further assembly of a 1D iron-chain-like structure into a 3D microporous framework by extra CuII ions (Figure e). This unique assembly adds a new variable to the toolbox of our present studies. Compound 7 forms three axial channels going through its void structure. The solvent molecules are trapped uncoordinatedly inside the framework. The total solvent-accessible volume in the unit cell is 1597.8 Ǻ3 for 7, accounting for approximately 29.5% of the total cell volume as calculated by PLATON. The disorder was limited to the solvents and may be due to the large amount of available space in the channels of the structure.

Thermal Analysis

Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed using a Pyris Diamond thermal analyzer. Approximately 20 mg of products 1–8 were heated under a N2 atmosphere in the temperature range RT-800 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C min–1. As shown in Figure , TGA of samples 1–8 indicates that their host frameworks are stable up to 200 °C and are finally converted into the crystalline copper oxides in agreement with the overall mass loss (approximately 78 wt %). The TG curves of 1–2 show that the thermal decompositions take place in three stages: (1) First, removing coordinated alcohol molecules (weight loss: for 1, observed: 4.86 wt %, calc: 6.02 wt %; for 2, observed: 5.93 wt %, calc: 8.44 wt %); (2) The second stage is a process to eliminate the tea ligand within the range of 210–300 °C; (3) finally, decomposing organic oba linkers above 300 °C. The release of the tea ligand prior to the organic oba linker has been documented. In comparison with the TG behaviors of 1–2, thermal decomposition of 6 has no sudden desolvented stage which suggests the stronger coordination interactions between alcohol molecule and host framework. Compounds 3, 7, and 8 are characterized by a desolvented process corresponding to the removal of lattice alcohol molecules. The events agree well with single-crystal X-ray diffraction studies. The final weight loss of residue for 7 is lower (approximate 70 wt %) than those of any other compounds, which agrees well with its proposed structure with extra copper ion. No weight loss is observed for 4 until 200 °C and for 5 until 150 °C. The TGA analysis of 5 indicates that coordination H2O molecules and tea ligand are lost in continuous steps in the range of 150–300 °C, with weight loss of 30.20 wt % (calc: 32.09 wt %), and it is difficult to assign each weight loss separately.

Gas Adsorption and Desorption Studies

The framework stability of samples 7 provides an opportunity to probe gas adsorption properties. Compound 7 exhibits a porous framework from single-crystal X-ray diffraction study and can retain the host framework toward thermal treatment from a desolvented process. We examined the permanent porosity of 7 generated by activation under high vacuum at 180 °C for 24 h. Standard N2 sorption measurements revealed that, as expected from the structural analysis, the porosity could be detected corresponding to the appreciable adsorbed amount of 81.75 cm3g–1 at 0.98 P/P 0 and 196 K (Figure ). Moreover, the isotherm exhibited large hysteretic desorption behavior, suggesting the existence of molecular gates for its host framework. The isotherm gave an apparent Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) surface area of 159.4 m2 g–1 between relative pressures of 0.11 and 0.98, which is moderate.

Magnetic Properties

The temperature-dependent magnetic susceptibility of compounds 6–8 has been measured under a 1 kOe applied field in the temperature range of 2–300 K (Figure ). At room temperature (300 K) effective magnetic moments of 0.85 (6), 1.55 (7), and 1.13 cm3·K·mol–1 (8) were observed. With decreasing temperature the χM T values increase gradually and pass through maxima at 2.98 K, 2.05 cm3·K·mol–1 (6), 2.98 K, 2.82 cm3·K·mol–1 (7), and 9.5 K, 2.03 cm3·K·mol–1 (8). Such behavior is characteristic of predominant ferromagnetic exchange coupling in Cu3 SBUs. Moreover, ferromagnetic coupling in Cu3 SBUs is largely determined by the Cu3 conformation. For 7, the extra CuII ions interact with Cu3 SBUs to give an inorganic polynuclear chain with much more overlap between the magnetic orbitals of the copper centers, resulting in a higher χM T value. The exchange coupling among Cu3 centers is also influenced by whether the Cu3 SBUs is angled or linear. The corresponding χM T value of 6 is somewhat smaller than that of 8, confirming a slightly weak coupling among linear Cu3 SBUs.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Again, the most striking structural feature of 7 is the further assembly of a 1D iron-chain-like structure into a 3D microporous framework by extra CuII ions (Figure e). This unique assembly adds a new variable to the toolbox of our present studies. Compound 7 forms three axial channels going through its void structure. The solvent molecules are trapped uncoordinatedly inside the framework. The total solvent-accessible volume in the unit cell is 1597.8 Ǻ3 for 7, accounting for approximately 29.5% of the total cell volume as calculated by PLATON. The disorder was limited to the solvents and may be due to the large amount of available space in the channels of the structure.

Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed using a Pyris Diamond thermal analyzer. Approximately 20 mg of products 1-8 were heated under a N2 atmosphere in the temperature range RT-800 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C min-1. As shown in Figure , TGA of samples 1-8 indicates that their host frameworks are stable up to 200 °C and are finally converted into the crystalline copper oxides in agreement with the overall mass loss (approximately 78 wt %). The TG curves of 1-2 show that the thermal decompositions take place in three stages: (1) First, removing coordinated alcohol molecules (weight loss: for 1, observed: 4.86 wt %, calc: 6.02 wt %; for 2, observed: 5.93 wt %, calc: 8.44 wt %); (2) The second stage is a process to eliminate the tea ligand within the range of 210-300 °C; (3) finally, decomposing organic oba linkers above 300 °C. <fn id="t2fn1">
<label>a</label>
<p>Symmetry codes. For <bold>1</bold> #1 –<italic toggle="yes">x</italic>, –<italic toggle="yes">y</italic>, –<italic toggle="yes">z</italic> + 1. For <bold>2</bold> #1 –<italic toggle="yes">x</italic> +
2, –<italic toggle="yes">y</italic> + 1, –<italic toggle="yes">z</italic> + 1.
For <bold>3</bold> #1 –<italic toggle="yes">x</italic> + 2, –<italic toggle="yes">y</italic> + 1, –<italic toggle="yes">z</italic> + 1; #2 –<italic toggle="yes">x</italic> + 3/2, –<italic toggle="yes">y</italic> + 1/2, –<italic toggle="yes">z</italic> + 1. For <bold>4</bold> #1 –<italic toggle="yes">x</italic> +
3/2, <italic toggle="yes">y</italic> + 1/2, –<italic toggle="yes">z</italic> + 1/2; #2

cln_elements.content: Crystal structure of 7: (a) ORTEP view of coordination environments around polynuclear copper centers (thermal ellipsoid probability: 30%); (b) SBUs with inorganic polynuclear chain comprised of side-shared CuO4N square-pyramids (blue) and CuO6 octahedra (pink); (c) view of microporous 3D framework with inorganic SBUs linked alternately via biphenyl rings of oba; (d) packing diagrams of microporous 3D framework along the c axis, exhibiting a wheel-shaped profile. Three colors are used to evidence the different positions of Cu centers generated; and (e) a better insight into the draw-out wheel, representing the further assembly of the 1D iron-chain-like structure into a 3D microporous framework by extra CuII ions (black) (all hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity).

Three colors are used to evidence the different positions of Cu centers generated; and (e) a better insight into the draw-out wheel, representing the further assembly of the 1D iron-chain-like structure into a 3D microporous framework by extra CuII ions (black) (all hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity).
